header.title: Arbatel of Magick
header.category: Grimoire, Hermeticism, Renaissance Magic, Angelic Magic

central_thesis: Arbatel posits that true Magick is a divine wisdom, originating from God, and involves interacting with benevolent spirits (Olympick Spirits and Angels) for the illustration of God's glory and the benefit of mankind. It sharply distinguishes this 'divine Magick' from 'evil Magick' or sorcery, which involves commerce with demons and leads to destruction. The core idea is that through piety, unwavering faith, and adherence to divine will, a predestined Magician can access and utilize God's creation and the ministry of spirits for beneficial purposes, obtaining 'secrets' and performing 'works' that would otherwise be considered miraculous.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the work by lamenting the corruption of true Magick into diabolical sorcery over time. It defines 'Magus' as one conversant in divine things and 'Magick' as the art of worshipping God, sharply differentiating it from Witchcraft. Three kinds of true Magick are identified: Astrologie (judging events by star influences), Philosophy of Nature (extracting virtues from nature), and Divine Magick (the highest form, involving direct divine contemplation). The preface emphasizes the necessity of an unprejudiced mind and the challenges in restoring true Magick from obscurity.

This part outlines the complete structure of 'Arbatel' as containing nine Tomes and seven Septenaries of Aphorisms. It briefly lists and describes the nine distinct forms of Magick intended for explication: Isagoge (general precepts), Microcosmical Magick, Olympick Magick, Hesiodiacal and Homerical Magick, Romane or Sibylline Magick, Pythagorical Magick, Magick of Apollonius, Hermetical or Ægyptiacal Magick, and Prophetical Magick. The provided text primarily covers the Isagoge.

This section lays down the foundational moral and spiritual precepts for a Magician. Key themes include the importance of secrecy in magical knowledge, constant prayer and reliance on God through His Son, living a pious and vigilant life, obedience to good admonitions, constancy in words and deeds, resisting temptation, seeking heavenly things over earthly, and recognizing that divine intervention is the ultimate source of help. It stresses that Angels and Spirits of God are prompt to minister to those who follow these principles.

This septenary elaborates on the source of power in magical operations, stating that names and characters derive their efficacy from God's ordination, not inherent properties. It outlines a hierarchy of wisdom, from God to spiritual, corporal, and elemental creatures. The Magician's role is to understand and discern these creatures' offices for beneficial use. It reaffirms God's omnipotence and the Magician's responsibility to seek knowledge from divine sources, emphasizing faith and the honoring of God and His Son as paramount. It also warns against the abuses of Astrology and other arts, stressing divine guidance for true understanding.

This section introduces the 'Olympick spirits,' celestial entities inhabiting the firmament and stars, whose office is to declare destinies under divine permission. It names the seven Olympick Governors (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Hagith, Ophiel, Phul), corresponding to planetary influences, detailing their rule periods and specific powers (e.g., Aratron converting things to stone, Bethor raising to dignities, Och giving health and wisdom, Hagith governing Venereous things, Ophiel teaching arts, Phul changing metals). It provides an example prayer for invoking a Solar Spirit and stresses faith, vigilance, and avoiding long detention of spirits.

This part defines 'secrets' as divinely revealed knowledge unattainable by human industry, categorizing them into 'Great Secrets' (e.g., curing diseases, prolonging life, knowing God), 'Mean Secrets' (e.g., metal transmutation, astronomical miracles, physical secrets), and 'Lesser Secrets' (e.g., wealth, honors, professional success). It reiterates that the primary way to attain these secrets is through prayer, faith, and dependence on God. While characters and seals can be aids, they are subservient to faith and God's will. It warns against idolatry, the snares of the devil, and the misuse of divine gifts, emphasizing righteous conduct.

This septenary delves into the nature of spirits, distinguishing between divine ministers and those serving creatures, emphasizing God's ultimate governance over all actions, good or evil. It details how Magicians, through diligence and magical sciences, can attain worldly riches, glory, and dignities, referencing historical accounts of tutelar angels. It explains that a Magician can command 'Princes of the Kingdom' or their 'Nobles' to fulfill desires, provided they are not absolved by a succeeding Magician. Warnings are given against earthly desires and the deceptive nature of evil spirits, stressing the need for the Magician to remain under divine protection.

This section emphasizes simplicity and purity in magical experiments, stating that God and Nature ordain all things to specific ends. It highlights the power of spoken words and describes the 'Order' of creation, distinguishing creatures of light (filled with truth and grace) from creatures of darkness (subject to vanity and sin). Magick is twofold: from God to creatures of light for good, or from God to creatures of darkness (either compelled to good or permitted to punish). It further subdivides Magick by method and agent. A seven-fold preparation for the Magick Art is outlined, focusing on meditation, self-knowledge, worship, vigilance, understanding spirit assistance, faith, taciturnity, and justice.

This final septenary presents seven laws for governing the Magician's conduct, including acknowledging divine ordination of spirits, constant prayer, testing spirits, avoiding superstition and idolatry, shunning devilish imitations, and cleaving to God's gifts. It defines a true Magitian as one whom spiritual essences serve by God's grace, and an evil Magician as one whom evil spirits serve for destruction. It reiterates that a Magitian is predestinated, but diligence and faith can achieve certain forms of Magick. The section concludes by asserting that all Magick stems from God, with good Magick arising from obedience and the fear of God, while damnable Magick results from its loss, leading to the snares of the devil. It encourages careful discernment for a 'competent end of life and living'.

key_concepts.definition: The spiritual wisdom of the Ancients, the art of worshipping God, involving interaction with benevolent celestial spirits (Olympick Spirits, Angels) through divine grace for the glory of God and the benefit of mankind. It is explicitly differentiated from sorcery or witchcraft.
A person altogether conversant in things divine, a contemplator of divine and heavenly sciences. In 'Arbatel', a true Magus is born or divinely called, and operates through piety and God's will.

Unlawful arts effected by combination with the devil, or those who use evil spirits for destructive or selfish ends, resulting in 'calamities' and 'eternal destruction'. These practices are portrayed as the corrupted form of true Magick.

Celestial spirits inhabiting the firmament and stars, appointed by God to govern the world and declare destinies. They are planetary rulers, each with specific powers and jurisdictions, serving God and potentially the righteous Magician.

The seven principal Olympick Spirits corresponding to the traditional planets: Aratron (Saturn), Bethor (Jupiter), Phaleg (Mars), Och (Sun), Hagith (Venus), Ophiel (Mercury), and Phul (Moon). Each rules for a specific period and possesses distinct abilities related to their planetary attribution.

Seals or sigils given by the Olympick Spirits themselves, representing their office and power. These characters, when proposed by a Magician, serve as a means of communication and invocation, but their efficacy ultimately stems from God's ordination and the Magician's faith.

Divinely revealed knowledge or hidden truths in nature that are unattainable by human industry alone. These are categorized into 'Great,' 'Mean,' and 'Lesser' secrets, encompassing abilities from curing diseases and transmuting metals to gaining wisdom and understanding divine and natural phenomena.

The title of the first Tome of 'Arbatel', meaning 'introduction.' It contains the general precepts and foundational principles for the entire Art of Magick, emphasizing moral, spiritual, and preparatory requirements for the practitioner.
In 'Arbatel', this refers to the knowledge of the Word of God, ruling one's life according to God's word, and understanding the government of God by Angels and their mysteries.
The knowledge of natural things and wisdom in human affairs, given by God to man.
The antithesis of true wisdom; characterized by contempt for God, living according to the devil's will, ignorance of divine governance, idolatry, and atheism.
The knowledge and use of poisons in nature, and wisdom in all evil arts for the destruction of mankind, conducted in contempt of God.

practical_system.description: The 'Arbatel' system, as outlined in the Isagoge, presents a spiritual and ceremonial path to magic heavily reliant on divine ordination, faith, piety, and adherence to God's will. It posits that a true Magician, often predestined, can, through a virtuous life and constant prayer, attract and direct benevolent celestial spirits, particularly the seven Olympick Governors. The system focuses on obtaining 'secrets' (divine revelations) and effecting 'works' for the glory of God and the benefit of mankind, rather than for personal gain or harm. While specific ritualistic elements like 'Characters' and planetary timings are mentioned, the emphasis is predominantly on the Magician's internal state and divine approval over elaborate external paraphernalia.
tools: Faith and Piety: The most essential 'tools,' emphasizing a constant, righteous, and God-fearing life as the foundation for all magical operations.
Prayer: Direct communication with God, serving as the primary means of obtaining grace and facilitating spirit interaction.

Knowledge of Spirits' Names and Offices: Understanding the specific jurisdictions and powers of the Olympick Governors and other spirits is crucial for effective invocation and discerning their true nature.

Characters (Seals): Specific symbols or sigils associated with each Olympick Governor, presented or confirmed by the spirits themselves, used for communication and establishing connection during invocation.

Planetary Timing: Observing the correct astrological day and hour corresponding to the desired Olympick Spirit (e.g., Saturday for Aratron, Thursday for Bethor) to align with their ruling periods and manifest their powers more effectively.
rituals: General Invocation: Call upon the Name of the Lord through His only-begotten Son for all undertakings. Use spirits as God's ministers with reverence and peaceful demeanor, always for God's honor and the profit of self and neighbor. (Aphorism 2, 11)

Prayer for Guidance: Recourse to God for all secrets and desires. Example prayer (Aphorism 15): 'O Lord of heaven and earth, Creator and Maker of all things visible and invisible; I, though unworthy, by thy assistance call upon thee, through thy onely begotten Son Jesus Christ our Lord, that thou wilt give unto me thy holy Spirit, to direct me in thy truth unto all good. Amen.'

Invocation of Olympick Spirits: Observe the rising of the Sun on the specific day and hour ruled by the desired Olympick Spirit. Say a prayer, such as the example for a Solar Spirit (Aphorism 21): 'Omnipotent and eternal God, who hast ordained the whole creation for thy praise and glory, and for the salvation of man, I beseech thee that thou wouldst send thy Spirit N.N. of the solar order, who shall inform and teach me those things which I shall ask of him; or, that he may bring me medicine against the dropsie, &c. Nevertheless not my will be done, but thine, through Jesus Christ thy onely begotten Son, our Lord. Amen.'

Spirit Dismissal: After the spirit has answered, thank God and the spirit: 'Forasmuch as thou camest in peace, and quietly, and hast answered unto my petitions; I give thanks unto God, in whole Name thou camest: and now thou mayest depart in peace unto thy orders; and return to me again when I shall call thee by thy name, or by thy order, or by thy office, which is granted from the Creator. Amen.' The spirit should not be detained for more than an hour unless a familiar relationship is established.

Circle Construction (Symbolic/Potential Ritual): Aphorism 27 describes making a 'Circle with a center A, which is B. C. D. E. At the East let there be B.C. a square. At the North, C.D. At the West, D.E. And at the South, E.D. Divide the Several quadrants into seven parts... and again divided into four parts... to symbolize the seal of the secrets of the world.' While the text does not detail the *ritualistic use* of this circle, its description suggests a geomantic or celestial mapping for understanding divine influence, which in other grimoires would be a physical construction for protection and focus.

relevant_quotes.text: Of the Magic of the Ancients, The greatest Studie of Wisdom.

Magia est connexio a viro sapiente agentium per naturam cum patientibus, sibi, congruenter respondentibus, ut inde opera prodeant, non sine corum admiratione qui causam ignorant. (Magick is the connexion of natural agents and patients, answerable each to other, wrought by a wise man, to the bringing forth of such effects as are wonderful to those that know not their causes.)

Whosoever would know Secrets, let him know how to keep secret things secretly; and to reveal those things that are to be revealed, and to seal those things which are to be sealed: and not to give holy things to dogs, nor cast pearls before swine.
In all things call upon the Name of the Lord: and without prayer unto God through his onely-begotten son, do not thou undertake to do or think any thing.

The true and onely way to all secrets, is to have recourse unto God the Author of all good; and as Christ teacheth, In the first place seek ye the kingdom of God and his righteousness, and all these things shall be added unto you.

The first Law is this, That he know that such a Spirit is ordained unto him from God; and let him meditate that God is the beholder of all his thoughts and actions; therefore let him direct all the course of his life according to the rule prescribed in the word of God.

The conclusion therefore of this Isagoge is the same which we have above already spoken of, That even as there is one God, from whence is all good; and one sin, to wit, disobedience, against the will of the commanding God, from whence comes all evil; so that the fear of God is the beginning of all wisdom, and the profit of all Magick; for obedience to the will of God, followeth the fear of God; and after this, do follow the presence of God and of the holy Spirit, and the ministery of the holy Angels, and all good things out of the inexhaustible treasures of God.

critical_analysis.relevance: Arbatel of Magick holds significant relevance in the Western Esoteric tradition, particularly within the Grimoire current and Hermeticism. It presents a unique, pious, and explicitly Christocentric approach to angelic and planetary magic, contrasting sharply with more ambiguous or demonological grimoires. Its emphasis on divine sanction, the Magician's moral purity, and God's grace as the ultimate source of magical power provides a framework that reconciles Christian theology with operative magic. The text's detailed exposition of the seven Olympick spirits and their planetary correspondences has profoundly influenced subsequent magical systems, including those found in the Golden Dawn and later ceremonial magic traditions. It serves as a vital historical document for understanding the evolution of Renaissance occult philosophy and its attempts to integrate Neoplatonic, Kabbalistic, and Christian elements.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes practitioners of ceremonial magic, Hermeticists, and students of Renaissance occult philosophy who seek to understand and practice a form of magic rooted in divine connection and ethical conduct. It also appeals to academic researchers in Western Esotericism and Christian mystics interested in angelic hierarchies and their historical context. The text is specifically aimed at those aspiring to 'divine Magick' for beneficial and spiritual growth, warning against 'caco-Magicians' and those pursuing selfish or destructive ends.
